Hey Destin,

Not sure what the original purpose of the experiment was exactly (hardwood vs felt, and the effects of spacing?), but a couple things I was thinking about to improve the experiments was around the knocking them over and recording the speed.

First was knocking the dominoes over. I think you need a more precise mechanism for knocking dominoes over; something with a consistent speed and something that will hit the dominoes in a consistent spot on the dominoes. I feel like the varying speed at which you knock the first one over, will affect the overall speed of all of them falling. As well hitting them at the same spot is important, for the reason you noticed how the dominoes twisted and untwisted as they fell. I have a feeling if you were able to knock the first one over with force that was even or hit the centre of the first domino, that twisting would be eliminated (or lessened).

Second is the timing. Instead of having one camera that needs to travel, can you setup two cameras. You would have them pointed at the last and first (or 10 dominoes in from the first) and sync the camera footage with some sort of laser device. I am thinking using mirrors and prism you would have a single laser beam split into two directions which each camera could capture, send a quick laser burst, while the cameras are filming. You would then be able to sync the two footage streams, and time how long it takes x milliseconds for y amount dominoes it takes to fall over. This way you wouldn't need to try and capture all the dominoes with a moving camera, and you would only be concerned when the first and last domino was hit, vs finding when each domino hits. You wouldn't have found the twisting effect you mentioned but you would be able to have a real number to compare between two data sets.

You can see this earthbound rover out in the yard on Google Earth if you look at Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California.  The rover is located in the dirt area at the northeastern side of the campus.  The rover is a white rectangle just left of a smallish building with a tan roof.  That building is the one in the video that the rover is kept in.  If you zoom in on the rover you can see the 6 wheels.

Destin, you are repulsively devoted to the lie that is Nasa. I get that you want to live in denial because you work for them and you cling to the soothing lie that Nasa must be good somehow, but that's not what a good christian does. If you were an honest man you would ask questions about why the rover has moved at an average speed of 100 times slower than a garden snail. Why this affront to engineering isn't even capable of color fidelity like a 100$ tourist camera. Why the only video from it is a multiyear timelapse. And an ocean of addtional scathing questions because it is a criminally incompetent piece of engineering.
You might also ask why it doesn't use a laser drill and test the material in situ.
